Title: Second order ODE solution approach
Question:
Find a solution for the following second order ODE

x''(t)+(x'(t))^2+\sin(x(t))=0, \; x(0)=\pi,\;x'(0)=0.

I am familiar with the characteristics equations method or assuming y=e^{rx}, however both approaches seem unavailable for this equation.

I tried simplifying the equation by assuming that we only seek a solution around the point x(0)=\pi and therefore \sin(x)\approx-x, which reduces the problem to
x''+(x')^2-x=0.

From here I still don't see how to work around (x')^2
Answer:
The problem asks for a solution. Find one easiest, simplest solution.

If x''(t)=0 and x'(t)=0 then the equation becomes:

\sin(x(t))=0, \; x(0)=\pi

One solution is x(t) = \pi. My apologies for not being very mathy, but trivial solutions aren't wrong.

Title: How to integrate \int \frac{x^{2}+7(\sqrt[m]{x^{m}})+6}{\sqrt[m]{x^{m}}+1}dx ?
Question:
Q)How to integrate \int \frac{x^{2}+7(\sqrt[m]{x^{m}})+6}{\sqrt[m]{x^{m}}+1}dx ? m=2nn=

First of all my approach:

Let I=\int \frac{x^{2}+7(\sqrt[m]{x^{m}})+6}{\sqrt[m]{x^{m}}+1}dx

1) \sqrt[m]{x^{m}}=|x|=+x, then:

I=\int\frac{x^{2}+7x+6}{x+1}dx

\implies I=\int\frac{(x+6)(x+1)}{(x+1)}dx

\implies I=\int(x+6)dx

\implies I=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+6x+C

2) \sqrt[m]{x^{m}}=|x|=-x, then:

I=\int\frac{x^{2}-7x+6}{(1-x)}dx

\implies I=\int\frac{(x-6)(x-1)}{(1-x)}dx

\implies I=\int(6-x)dx

\implies I=6x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}+C_1

But my doubt is how to solve the integral in a single case by taking both the cases together? I am facing problem in solving this integral by taking both the cases together in a single case and then integrating.

\sqrt[m]{x^{m}}=|x|=+x2^{nd}\sqrt[m]{x^{m}}=|x|=-x
Answer:
It's not entirely clear what is meant by \sqrt[m]{x^m}.  This notation is unusual because if the intent is that \sqrt[m]{x^m} = |x|, presumably, the question should have simply used the absolute value notation.  If the intent is that \sqrt[m]{x^m} = x, again, the question should have been written that way.

If we assume the former--i.e. the intent is \sqrt[m]{x^m} = |x|--then we may write for all real x
\frac{x^2 + 7|x| + 6}{|x| + 1} = \frac{|x|^2 + 7|x| + 6}{|x| + 1} = \frac{(|x| + 1)(|x| + 6)}{|x| + 1} = |x| + 6.  Cancellation is allowed because |x| + 1 > 0.
Then integration proceeds as usual:
\int |x| + 6 \, dx = \frac{x|x|}{2} + 6x + C = x\left(\frac{|x|}{2} + 6 \right) + C.

Title: Can we say that 1^\infty is indeterminate because we can't classify \infty as even or odd?
Question:
While studying indeterminate forms I like many others had used this post to understand why 1^\infty is indeterminate. Today I thought of a new and perhaps simpler argument to explain why this is so but I couldn't find it among the answers in the post.
My argument is that we can write 1^x = (-1)^{2.x}
Now if x = \infty, then 1^\infty = (-1)^{\infty},
Which is only true if we can say infinity is even or odd which we can't say.
So, am I correct, or I have made some mistakes in my assumptions.
Answer:
No, your argument is not correct. The issue of 1^\infty being an indeterminate form has nothing to do with integer exponents per se; one is instead interested in real valued exponents approaching \infty. It also has nothing to do with changing the base to -1, which on the infinitesmal scale of limits is far, far away from 1; one is instead interested in real valued bases approaching 1.

I suggest simply reading the accepted answer of the post you linked to. In brief summary, what matters are the values of the expression b^x as one lets the base b approach 1 and the exponent x approach \infty: the limiting value is not well defined. That's what makes the expression 1^\infty an indeterminate form.

Title: Can there be more than one global maximums of a function?
Question:
The definition(wiki): A real-valued function f defined on a domain X has a global (or absolute) maximum point at xâˆ—, if f(xâˆ—) \geq f(x) for all x in X.

My question is can there be more than one global maximum(or minimum) of a function?

The definition does not suggest that there is only 1 global maximum(or minimum). Example: let f(x) = x^2 on the domain X = [-2,2], thus the global maximum is f(-2) = 4 = f(2) as by definition f(-2)  = f(2) \geq f(x) \ \forall x\in X, thus we have 2 global maiximums.

I tried to confirm this but there are so many sorces saying that there can only be one:
Example1, Example2.

Am I misunderstanding something? I would appreciate any insight you can offer.
Answer:
The term "maximum" applies to the y-coordinate or output of the function.  In your case, 4 is the sole largest y-coordinate, though it appears twice.  So the location of the maximum y need not be unique, but the y-value will be unique.

Note that in your definition, you have a "maximum point at x^*."  This does not say that x^* is the maximum. (And it's not, that would be f(x^*).)

Title: A generalization of integration by parts
Question:
Many years ago, I came up with a short generalization of integration by parts that was definitely known, but I could never find a reference for it. I was considering throwing it on arxiv, but before I do, is anyone aware of it?

For k a positive integer, let f^{(k)}(x) denote the kth derivative and f^{(-k)} denote a choice of kth antiderivative.

By iterating the product rule, we see that for positive k:

(fg)^{(k)}=\sum\limits_{r\ge 0} \binom{k}{r} f^{(k-r)}g^{(r)}.

(Since k is positive, \binom{k}{r}=0 when r>k)

The generalization is simply that this holds for negative k as well, under certain conditions that allow the sum to converge nicely. For example, for k=-1, this gives the ``tabular" method of integration by parts:

(fg)^{(-1)}=\sum\limits_{r\ge 0} (-1)^r f^{(-1-r)}g^{(r)}

One can obtain a short proof of the generalization by comparing this to multiplying a certain formal power series expansion of (x+y)^{-k} by
(x+y)^k.

An easy set of conditions where this applies is when g(x) is a polynomial. A more non-trivial set of conditions where the above formula seems to hold is when g(x) is analytic for some |x-a|<r, the effective supremum of f is bounded on this interval (or on all finite intervals if r=\infty), and we choose our anti-derivatives such that

f^{(-k)}(x)=\int\limits_a^x f^{(-k+1)}(s)ds

Title: Prove or disprove that the limit of subsequence infima equals the limit of sequence
Question:
Consider some convergent bounded sequence (a_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}} in \mathbb{R}. Define the sequence (b_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}} by b_n=\inf\{a_n,a_{n+1},a_{n+2},\cdots\}. Assume this infimum exists. Prove or disprove that \lim_{n\to\infty}a_n = \lim_{n\to\infty}b_n.

I have proven that the sequence (b_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}} is increasing and bounded above, meaning that it must have a limit at its supremum. I have also proven that the limits are the same in the case where (a_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}} is increasing, but I do not know how to prove this in the general case, especially where (a_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}} is convergent but not monotone. How should I continue my proof?
Answer:
Yes. We have that \lim_{n}a_{n}=\lim_{n}b_{n}, provided
that \lim_{n}a_{n} exists. Let l=\lim_{n}a_{n}. Here, we consider
the case l\in\mathbb{R} only. (acutally, the equality continues
to hold if l=+\infty or l=-\infty)

Let \varepsilon>0 be arbitrary, then there exists N such that
a_{n}\in(l-\varepsilon,l+\varepsilon) whenever n\geq N. For
n\geq N, a_{n}\geq l-\varepsilon implies that b_{n}=\inf\{a_{n},a_{n+1},\ldots\}\geq l-\varepsilon.
Moreover, for n\geq N, b_{n}=\inf\{a_{n},a_{n+1},\ldots\}\leq a_{n}\leq l+\varepsilon.
This shows that l-\varepsilon\leq b_{n}\leq l+\varepsilon. As (b_{n})
is monotonic increasing and bounded above by l+\varepsilon, \lim_{n}b_{n}
exists. Letting n\rightarrow\infty, we obtain l-\varepsilon\leq\lim_{n}b_{n}\leq l+\varepsilon.
That is, |\lim_{n}b_{n}-l|\leq\varepsilon. Since \varepsilon>0
is arbitrary, we conclude that |\lim_{n}b_{n}-l|=0, i.e., \lim_{n}a_{n}=\lim_{n}b_{n}.

Realizing that this difference really should have been q - s, the function can be corrected by adding a linear function to it. In other words, adjusting b by adding \frac{q - s - (a (p^2 - r^2) + b (p - r))}{p - r} to it.

This then leads to:

a = \frac{t - u}{2(p - r)} \\
b = \frac{puâˆ’rt}{p - r} + \frac{q - s - (\frac{t - u}{2(p - r)} (p^2 - r^2) + \frac{puâˆ’rt}{p - r} (p - r))}{p - r} =
\frac{puâˆ’rt+q-s+\frac{(u-t)(p+r)}{2}+rt-pu}{p - r}=

Strangely enough this is not equal to what xpaul did get...

Edit2

I was forced to reformulate my question, which is now posted here: Fitting a parabola through two points in which the derivatives are known with the aim of finding a minimum.
Answer:
A parabolic function has the equation

f(x) = a x^2 + b x + c

It is fully determined by three parameters which are a,b,c.

The given conditions in the problem lead to the fully overdetermined linear system in a,b,c:

a p^2 + b p + c = q

a r^2 + b r + c = s

2 a p + b = t

2 a r + b = u

Since you want the first two equations to be satisfied by (a,b,c), then you have to solve the smaller underdetermined system

a p^2 + b p + c = q

a r^2 + b r + c = s

This is a rank 2 system, and its solution will be of the form

[a,b,c]^T = X_0 + \lambda X_1

where X_0, X_1 are known 3-vectors, and \lambda is a free parameter, \lambda \in \mathbb{R}.

Now we want the error in f'(p) and f'(r) to be equal, i.e. we want

2 a p + b - t = 2 a r + b - u

This simplifies to

2 a (p - q) = t - u

Since a linearly depends on X_{01} and X_{11} , then this condition can always be satisfied.

Title: Trying to understand coordinate transformations
Question:
So, I don't really understand why \mathrm{d}x or generally any differential is equal to the sum of this differential over each one of the corresponding spherical coordinates times each spherical coordinate. Where is the following derived from?
\mathrm{d}x = \frac{\partial x}{\partial r}\mathrm{d}r + \frac{\partial x}{\partial \theta}\mathrm{d}\theta + \frac{\partial x}{\partial \phi}\mathrm{d}\phi
or in general,
\mathrm{d}x_\nu = \sum_{\sigma=1}^3\frac{\partial x_\nu}{\partial x'_\sigma}\mathrm{d}x'_\sigma
Answer:
It looks like you are trying to state the chain rule, one of the fundamental laws of calculus, which relates total d and partial \partial derivatives. For a function f(x_1,x_2,...,x_n)

df=\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1}dx_1 + \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2}dx_2+...+\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_n}dx_n

This can be understood heuristically as follows: let us say that f(x,y)
is the height f of a surface at any coordinate point (x,y).  As an example, let us try to find the change in vertical height f between two points on this oddly sloped table.

It is sloped in both the x and y directions shown, and those slopes are different, but they are constant in each direction.

Going from points f_0 to f_1, if we travel first a distance dy, the change in height over that distance is f_y~dy, where f_y is the slope in the y direction.  We then move a distance dx in the x direction, with our height changing by a further  f_x~dx, where f_x is the slope in the x direction.  (Note, red dotted lines are lines of constant height, parallel to the floor).

The total height change from f_0 to f_1 is the sum of the solid red lines:

df=f_x~dx + f_y~dy

And the slopes f_x and f_y are nothing but the partial derivatives \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} and \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}.

Therefore:

df=\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}dx + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}dy

which is the chain rule.  This can be extended to any number of independent (i.e. orthogonal) variables.

Because we are considering small (infinitesimal) changes, a surface or function of arbitrary overall shape will take the form of a plane like the table shown, with a constant linear slope in the direction of each variable â€“ in the same way that in \rm 1D calculus, any smooth curve becomes a straight line if you zoom in to an infinitesimal distance.  So this analysis applies to any smooth surface or function (i.e. with no holes or other exotic features).

SIDE NOTE: In general relativity or curved spaces in general (per the original question), the chain rule and the product rule are the same, but when differentiating vectors you have to account for both the vector magnitude and the unit vector itself changing with location, i.e.

\frac{\partial}{\partial x_i}\vec{\bf v}~=~\frac{\partial}{\partial x_i}\left(v_j\bf{\vec{e}_j}\right)~=~\frac{\partial v_j}{\partial x_i}\boldsymbol{\vec{e}_j}+v_j\frac{\partial  \boldsymbol{\vec{e}_j}}{\partial x_i}

Title: if f,g are differentiable s.t. f(x)=g(x)+o(x^n) , then is \frac{df(x)}{dx} = \frac{dg(x)}{dx}+o(x^{n-1}) ? [closed]

Title: Integral with min
Question:
While solving some problem, I have reached an intermediate step in which I need to calculate the following integral:

\int_0^1\min (x,1-x) \cdot x dx

I'm stuck with the calculation, trying to use some kind of geometric trick here. I will be glad to have some of your ideas.
Answer:
As @hamam_Abdallah stated in his comment, there holds

\min(x,1-x) = x \iff x \leqslant 1/2.

Therefore, you can compute your integral as follows:

\int_0^1 \min(x,1-x) \cdot x \, dx = \int_0^{1/2} x^2 \, dx + \int_{1/2}^1 (1-x) x\, dx.

I believe you should be able to compute the latter two integrals, but if you need more details about this last calculation please let me know.

Title: How to integrate \int \frac{x^{2}+7(\sqrt[m]{x^{m}})+6}{\sqrt[m]{x^{m}}+1}dx ?
Question:
Q)How to integrate \int \frac{x^{2}+7(\sqrt[m]{x^{m}})+6}{\sqrt[m]{x^{m}}+1}dx ? m=2nn=

First of all my approach:

Let I=\int \frac{x^{2}+7(\sqrt[m]{x^{m}})+6}{\sqrt[m]{x^{m}}+1}dx

1) \sqrt[m]{x^{m}}=|x|=+x, then:

I=\int\frac{x^{2}+7x+6}{x+1}dx

\implies I=\int\frac{(x+6)(x+1)}{(x+1)}dx

\implies I=\int(x+6)dx

\implies I=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+6x+C

2) \sqrt[m]{x^{m}}=|x|=-x, then:

I=\int\frac{x^{2}-7x+6}{(1-x)}dx

\implies I=\int\frac{(x-6)(x-1)}{(1-x)}dx

\implies I=\int(6-x)dx

\implies I=6x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}+C_1

But my doubt is how to solve the integral in a single case by taking both the cases together? I am facing problem in solving this integral by taking both the cases together in a single case and then integrating.

\sqrt[m]{x^{m}}=|x|=+x2^{nd}\sqrt[m]{x^{m}}=|x|=-x
Answer:
It's not entirely clear what is meant by \sqrt[m]{x^m}.  This notation is unusual because if the intent is that \sqrt[m]{x^m} = |x|, presumably, the question should have simply used the absolute value notation.  If the intent is that \sqrt[m]{x^m} = x, again, the question should have been written that way.

If we assume the former--i.e. the intent is \sqrt[m]{x^m} = |x|--then we may write for all real x
\frac{x^2 + 7|x| + 6}{|x| + 1} = \frac{|x|^2 + 7|x| + 6}{|x| + 1} = \frac{(|x| + 1)(|x| + 6)}{|x| + 1} = |x| + 6.  Cancellation is allowed because |x| + 1 > 0.
Then integration proceeds as usual:
\int |x| + 6 \, dx = \frac{x|x|}{2} + 6x + C = x\left(\frac{|x|}{2} + 6 \right) + C.

Title: Can we say that 1^\infty is indeterminate because we can't classify \infty as even or odd?
Question:
While studying indeterminate forms I like many others had used this post to understand why 1^\infty is indeterminate. Today I thought of a new and perhaps simpler argument to explain why this is so but I couldn't find it among the answers in the post.
My argument is that we can write 1^x = (-1)^{2.x}
Now if x = \infty, then 1^\infty = (-1)^{\infty},
Which is only true if we can say infinity is even or odd which we can't say.
So, am I correct, or I have made some mistakes in my assumptions.
Answer:
No, your argument is not correct. The issue of 1^\infty being an indeterminate form has nothing to do with integer exponents per se; one is instead interested in real valued exponents approaching \infty. It also has nothing to do with changing the base to -1, which on the infinitesmal scale of limits is far, far away from 1; one is instead interested in real valued bases approaching 1.

I suggest simply reading the accepted answer of the post you linked to. In brief summary, what matters are the values of the expression b^x as one lets the base b approach 1 and the exponent x approach \infty: the limiting value is not well defined. That's what makes the expression 1^\infty an indeterminate form.
